Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 09:47PM MelanieW wrote: Leah called me and told me.  We are both just sick about this.  I know that a plan is already underway and you can still beat this.  We are all pulling for you and we will be here.  I know the rads will zap your energy, but please let me know when you feel up to me flying out to see you.  You have amazing energy and that will help you so much in this fight.  I am just plain mad about this.  Love you lots....
Posts.Title: PET/CT shows bone and liver mets marshakb nancyc

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 03:50PM MelanieW wrote: Love you too... I plan on getting out there to see you real soon.  If you feel like the "royal treatment"...then you shall have it! I too have wondered about some of the drugs like Zometa as a preventative.  I intend to ask my onc about this on my next visit.  I understand that insurance companies do not want to tread there because of the financial aspects.  But isn't bone mets the most common from bc?  Once dx'd with mets, then the insurance companies will certainly pay out more than they would trying to prevent it.  And no...you are not dead yet...not even close.  I think you will see that more and more as these ladies who have fought and won continue to come here to encourage you.

Posts.Title: Shortness of breath with Tykerb and Xeloda? deb711 deb711

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 08:58PM MelanieW wrote: I actually did 6 rounds (one arm also) without the port.  I did develop phlebitis after round 2 and they figured that I would need a port.  My onc said he does not do a port unless he has to.  He said the port has its problems also.  After the phlebits, I would keep a moist electric heating pad wrapped around my arm following each treatment.  I would do this for about a week following each tx.  I also had to do weekly blood draws and that was hard on my veins.  It has been a little over a year since finishing and my veins look pretty good.

Posts.Title: helping a sister in need LuAnnH whoopsiedoodles

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 12:20PM - edited Feb 11, 2008 04:45PM by MelanieW Hello Ladies! I am from the Feb 2007 chemo group.  I just wanted to drop in and tell you all that we are thinking of you as you start your tx. After reading your posts, I want to add something.  I never took sleeping pills prior to chemo, but I found I just could not sleep without them.  Don't be afraid to ask for something.  The steroids will wind you up.  It's awful to feel so tired, but not be able to sleep.  I used them the first week following each tx.  As for ports.  I know a couple of you are still trying to decide.  I did it without one.  I did Tax/Cy/Epi every 3 weeks and had bloodwork every week.  I really did not think my veins would make it since we could only use one arm.  I developed phlebitis after tx #2.  This was a red inflamed, hard area.  They treated it with antibiotics and warm moist towels to the area.  After that, I would wrap my arm with a moist heating pad for 20 mins several times per day...especially the 10 days following tx.  I only had that one issue with phlebitis and I am happy and feel lucky that I made it through without a port.  Neulasta shot.  These were always given in my arm.  I had very minimal side effects.  I have heard that if you are giving them to yourself, then it does need to be in the stomach. This can be such an emotional roller coaster ride.  It is so important that you ladies stick together through it all.  Keep supporting each other.  We started a secret pal game that worked really nice.  One husband in the group collected the names of those who wanted to participate.  Assigned each a secret pal, sent an email survery to find out favorite colors, favorite treats, likes and dislikes.  Then sent that to their SP.  We did it for a couple of months.  It was nice to get a card or ecard or little gifts.  We set a spending limit of $5 per gift.  We actually did this after we completed chemo.  But it might be uplifting during chemo! Huggzz to you all....
